of Inhibition. Science, Art and Fungi
Pathogen Population Biology and Disease Management
Epidemiology of Leptosphaeria maculans and L. biglobosa, causal agents of phoma stem canker of oilseed rape
Effects of geographical location on phoma stem canker and yield of oilseed rape crops in the UK

• Phoma stem canker, caused by L. maculans and L. biglobosa, is a serious disease of winter oilseed rape that results in considerable yield loss. L. maculans is the most important pathogen, it produces the typical large leaf spots, with numerous pycnidia

• L. maculans has several races dependant on the genetic makeup of the individuals within the pathogen population. These interact with resistance genes in the cultivars so that some races are able to infect specific cultivars whilst others cannot.

<li>The disease is primarily spread by wind-borne ascospores released in autumn from infected stubble of the previous seasons crop.  Plants infected soon after emergence develop the most severe stem canker symptoms the following spring/summer and backward crops suffer the greatest yield losses
<li>Fungicides are an efficient method for phoma control.  However, timing is crucial.

<li>Responses to fungicides are variable between crops. In general, where stem canker is moderate or severe and controlled by well-timed fungicide programmes there can be significant yield increases of up to over a tonne/ha.

<li>TAG (The Arable Group) has, in general, measured smaller yield benefits from its control than Rothamsted and ADAS.  This PhD project will investigate the reasons for the disparity in fungicide yield responses between sites, which could be due to a number of factors including the aggressiveness of the disease

In the UK, around £12 million per annum is spent on fungicides for the control of oilseed rape diseases. However, there is concern that fungicides are being used inappropriately. Survey data showed stem canker was still severe after fungicide use in eastern England, suggesting that spray timing was poor. The overuse and misuse of fungicides increases the potential to select for fungicide resistance and also results in unnecessary expense for the grower. In addition, compaction of tramlines by spray applications in late autumn may result in soil erosion. It is therefore important that clear guidelines and recommendations are developed to ensure that fungicides are applied at the correct dose and the best time.

A study by Rothamsted Research and ADAS, funded by the HGCA, suggests that application of fungicide to winter oilseed rape, once a threshold incidence of affected plants has been surpassed, can decrease severity of phoma stem canker and increase yield.

However, experiments done by TAG, at locations throughout England produced different results. Yield responses to fungicides were not significant unless light leaf spot was also present. In this work, significant responses to the control of phoma stem canker through fungicide treatments were observed only occasionally even when a threshold incidence of affected plants had been exceeded. In addition, in contrast to the results of Rothamsted/ADAS, significant responses to stem canker control were generally not observed through fungicide treatments after November. At TAG sites, although the percentage of stems with canker was reduced following increased fungicide application, the yield did not increase.

So, what are the causes of the differences observed in the results of these studies, geographical?, climatical?, agronomical?, biological (the host crop and/or the aggressiveness of the pathogen)? Are the differences simply due to different climatic conditions at different geographic locations? For example, in some areas of England there may be differences in crop growth rates in relation to fungal invasion? Or perhaps there may be differences in the ratio of the two fungal species and their component races that cause the disease, with populations in some areas being more aggressive than in other areas? Alternatively there may a fungicide insensitivity (resistance) problem in some areas of the country?

To attempt to answer some of these questions, this PhD project begins this October. The project aims to investigate why there are differences between the results of Rothamsted/ADAS and TAG experiments in an attempt to clarify fungicide requirements in different geographic regions of oilseed rape production in England.
The project will also involve TAG farmer members as well as the TAG research teams.

The first task is to ask the industry how it grows its oilseed rape. This will involve a postal and telephone survey of TAG members and HGCA levy payers to investigate local variation in field experience of disease control on winter oilseed rape in the UK. Factors such as location, soil type, agronomy, fungicide use and final yield will be assessed to determine if any patterns emerge from what growers and their advisers do in the field.

The progress of phoma stem canker will also be monitored at TAG and other experimental sites across the UK. The timing of fungicide application and influence of other diseases, such as light leaf spot, will also be studied.

In addition, a Leptosphaeria isolate survey will be done at six TAG sites across England. Here a spring variety with no known resistance genes (cv. Drakkar) will be sown in the autumn for the sole purpose of being a trap crop. In the absence of resistance genes, there should be no selection pressure on the pathogen population and each individual in the population should be able to infect the trap crop as easily as the next. So the survey should result in the collection of a typical sub-sample of the pathogen population. The individual isolates will then be tested on varieties that contain known Rlm (resistance to L. maculans) genes to provide a snap-shot of the race structure across the country. A similar large scale survey of the L. maculans population in France and, on a smaller scale, across Europe produced a fascinating insight into the distribution of the races and provide valuable information on what cultivars should (or more importantly, should not!) be grown in certain areas. Isolates will also be tested for fungicide insensitivity (resistance).

This work should give a greater understanding of the interactions between the oilseed rape host and L. maculans/L. biglobosa, and that this enhanced knowledge will allow a reduction in the levels of fungicide currently applied to oilseed rape crops. This will decrease costs for growers and possibly prevent both soil erosion and the development of fungicide resistance.

The results of this three year study will be communicated to growers through the agricultural press as well as through presentations and demonstrations at TAG field days and meetings and possibly at HGCA organised events. Visit back to see how the project is progressing.

The project is funded by HGCA, The Morley Agricultural Foundation and The Chadacre Agricultural Trust. I am based at Rothamsted Research under the supervision of Dr Neal Evans and Prof. Bruce D L Fitt and am registered at the University of Nottingham under the supervision of Dr Steve Rossall at Sutton Bonington Campus.
